Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Identifying phylogenetically informative data from next-generation sequencing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Knowledge of evolutionary relationships among species forms the fundamental basis for research in fields ranging from agriculture to ecology to medicine. This project aims to develop new methods and software to rapidly process large genomic datasets and extract information that helps improve our understanding of these relationships. This project will provide extensive bioinformatics training for 3-6undergraduates; computer exercises will be developed to engage hundreds of additional undergraduates in college courses. Research updates and explanations will be provided to the scientific community at annual conferences, and to the general public through the popular science weblog, The Panda?s Thumb (http://www.pandasthumb.org/).

This research seeks to develop software that will facilitate numerous projects in the field of evolution, including research on non-model organisms and emerging infectious diseases. First, this research will produce a method to identify regions of the genome that are similar enough that they can be compared among diverse groups. Second, new statistical models will be developed to accurately determine the sequence for each species for these regions given the error in current methods of genome sequencing. Third, methods will be developed to automate the identification of data that is useful to determine both recent and ancient evolutionary events. The resulting data can be used in established analytical software platforms. The methods developed by this project will be made available to the scientific community as robust, easy-to-use software at https://github.com/rachelss/SISRS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the important challenges in modern biology is to accurately resolve evolutionary relationships. Our understanding of these relationships forms the fundamental basis for research in fields ranging from ecology to medicine. For example, knowledge of evolutionary relationships has allowed us to understand the structure of ecological communities, how speciation and diversification occur, identify origins, reservoirs, and transmission pathways of diseases, and determine how cancer metastasizes. Phylogenetics is the field that specializes in the study of evolutionary relationships and has traditionally relied on limited, but highly curated datasets, e.g. a few well known genes. The major goals of this project was to develop new methods to rapidly identify phylogenetic markers from large modern genomic datasets and to implement these methods in easy-to-use open-source software.

During this project, we developed SISRS, a program to identify large numbers of markers containing phylogenetic signal from datasets constructed through whole-genome and/or whole-exome sequencing of multiple species. SISRS is an open-source software project available at https://github.com/rachelss/SISRS/ and is released under the GNU General Public License version 3. SISRS directly analyzes genomic sequencing reads and avoids the time consuming steps of de novo whole genome assembly, multiple genome alignment, and annotation. SISRS simplifies the identification of phylogenetic markers and can accurately identify thousands of markers much quicker than standard procedures. SISRS has been used to study evolutionary relationships in many taxa, including mammals, birds, plants, and pathogens. Using SIRSR, we determined that debates about relationships among large mammalian groups is related to choices made during dataset construction. We also studied the evolutionary relationships of Leishmania, the genus of unicellular organism responsible for the disease leishmaniasis, and determined that their biogeography and divergence dates are consistent with an ancient dispersal of the genus.

This project also supported the development of educational activities for Arizona State University's yearly, campus-wide public outreach event: Night of the Open Door. Activities included phylogenetic exercises, computational biology demonstrations, and information about interesting genetic traits. Broader outreach was achieved via the publication of articles about phylogenetics and genomics at the population science blog, The Panda's Thumb.
